content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												A brand new Greek epic.  Huge story, brilliant design, outstanding 2D open world to explore.Each level has a unique twist to it that makes it stand out (Hades has enemies that respawn, Zeus' Palace rains lightning down on you, Ares' lair has respawning enemies that fight each other, Poseidon's area is all aquatic with underwater enemies found nowhere else).  Though the game pretty much is made of branching destroy-this-kill-that quests, the ways you have to execute them are all different.  This makes every quest unique, and every area a surprise.Each boss fight is special as well, keenly balanced for just the right amount of challenge without ever becoming frustrating.  The final battle with Zeus is blissfully unfair, requires strategy and thought to win, and never made me ragequit.The story is simple, and in any other context would be cliched, but it's appropriate here.  Overthrowing the gods who decided humanity must be extinguished is grand, epic, and engrossing.  I had to know how it ended, and find out what happens to the people I met along the way.Combat takes some getting used to, and switching weapons or using health and potions during combat leaves you vulnerable.  There's no way to switch to a weapon or potion directly; you have to use the mouse wheel to scroll through your inventory, and that can make it frustrating to use something in the heat of battle.Platforming can be awkward with keyboard and mouse, and I didn't get used to it until the end of the game, but there's really no way around it.  Again, it is challenging, but never frustrating.Apotheon is superbly designed, well-balanced, and a joy to explore.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												Gorgeous. I'm a sucker for pretty games, and Apotheon is an exquisitely pretty game. Pros: It's beautiful. The art style pulls you in and keeps you interested for a long time. There are lots of interesting mini-games, secret areas, unique challenges, and a mostly open map for exploring. Cons: Levels are a smidge too large, and the gameplay is quite long. This means the game risks over-staying its welcome as some of the levels can turn into a grind. Also the controls are clunky and can be intensely frustrating at first. You have to retrain your expectations for scroller controls and you have to use a mouse in order to enjoy the game. Unfortunately, despite being a scroller, this also makes the game almost impossible to play on a steam controller, which was a disappointment. That being said, it is a game that is absolutely worth purchasing and enjoying the presentation of, even if you end up not finishing it. Come for the artwork, stay for the artwork.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Apotheon was a little game that i'd never even known about up until its release. I believe I read a small review about it and shortly after checked out its Steam page. Immediately its art style hooked me as i've always been a fan of Roman and Greek mythology as well as their cultures. I also love the history and combat from the era and when I saw this game was done entirely in Greek mythology art style I decided I was going to go in blind on this game and just buy it there and then. It looked great and it met any expectations I had. It was a bit of a different game than I expected. Its a Metroidvania type game that is similar to a lot of the recent 2D platformers from the current era. Its challenging combat and beautiful art and animations immediately grabbed me and that was just the scratching the surface. As I got into the game I found it had more depth than I expected, varied weapons and items, fun secrets and side missions, great sound and voice acting and just a huge charm which made it feel so unique even though there are so many other Metroidvania games out there. Everything in the visuals department sets Apotheon apart from other games and its amazing animation quality plays into the combat and gives it a very, very deliberate and visceral feel. They really did an amazing job on it and it stood out to me through my entire experience. Its a combat system that is a bit finnicky at first, is so satisfying once accustomed to and difficult to master. The combat I really feel makes this game worth playing and truly was handled perfectly to match the style of this game. Apotheon also controls fantastically, again it took a bit of getting used to because the game is animation heavy but once you get used to it the feeling of momentum from running and jumping just feels wonderfully on keyboard or controller. The same can be said for the combat as each blow landed feels visceral and has impact. The combat is deliberate, every attack commits your character to the action so the combat takes on a bit of a Dark Souls feel where some thought and patience is required to really accell at it. The game features a fairly large number of bosses each with their own challenges. The game never felt like it was getting stale as it threw in new twists to the combat at every turn with new enemy types and new level types to fight in. In one level you can barely see, its pitch black and you only have a torch to light the way a few meters in front of you. In another level you're battling mermen under water which restricts your ability to use ranged weapons accept for one which was made for the mermen's use. The voice acting is top notch and every God character has personality and identities. The story was well done and well told with lots of cool lore and history on the Greek Gods and every weapon and piece of armor has its own model and there are a lot of them. Theres a crafting system for consumables but its nothing to write home about. And each level looks beautiful and feels unique for the most part. The levels can blend together a bit because of how consistent the art style is but the color pallete is great and there are awesome contrasts and colors to give the game a really great feeling of majesty and beauty.Pros --Great combat system. Satisfying and brutal, pretty easy to learn yet hard to master.-Tons of different weapons, shields, items and armor each with their own unique models.-Expansive levels with lots of secrets and items to be found as well as enemies to fight.-Varied enemies.-Great voice acting-Strong, well told story.-Beautiful art style and color scheme.-Authentic feeling environment.-Awesome final battle. Cons --Weak crafting system.-Boss fights can be unintuitive at first.-Combat encounters can get a little repetative at times though not often.-Normal difficulty isn't very challenging, I felt very overpowered by the end of the game.All in all this game is absolutely worth $15 for my money. It was bigger, badder and better than I expected it to be. It lasted about 15 hours for 1 play through though, its probably realistically closer to 10-12 hours. It has multiple difficulty settings for extra play time as well as a multiplayer mode. I've not tried the Multiplayer so I can't speak for it but if it uses the combat system and runs smoothly I imagine its a lot of fun. I just bought this game not expecting the amount of detail and care that I found once I played it and it really suprised me. It was one of my favorite suprises in gaming in recent memory and I'd recommend it to anyone. It really is a fantastic Indie and is so masterfully crafted that it deserves more attention than its gotten. I'm not big on giving a number score to games but if I had to give this game a scroe, i'd give it...8.5/10

Posted: February 15, 2015
												Apotheon is a game with an art style that's both unique and good looking. Everything feels right about the graphics and animations and it really does bring you into the mindset that this is a game about ancient greek mythology. The game has light RPG mechanics in where you can pick up multiple weapons and tools that are split into four categories; melee weapons, long ranged weapons, throwabale weapons/traps and potions/elixirs. The combat is pretty good, with fluid movement and some epic moments but it can get a little fiddly trying to change weapons in the middle of combat. It can also get quite annoying when some of your weapons overreach the enemies with weapons like the spear, the axe and the mace.What I would like to see is the ability to drop inferior weapons because scrolling to the right weapon can get frustrating when there's ten weapons between the one you want and with weapons breaking quickly you can't really set one as a primary. Spears should also stab and not get used as a club of some sort.

Posted: October 31, 2016
												Meh...This game seems like it could be interesting, but it's just lacking the polish necessary to make a good platformer.  One super important part to making a platformer enjoyable is mobility, I need to feel in complete control of my character.  You lose momentum whenever running over slight changes in terrain (e.g. from stairs to flat ground).  If you're running not in the direction of your mouse you move at cripplingly slow speeds.  The game just makes you feel clumsy.I'm personally not a huge fan of mouse-aim platformers, but if you are going to make such a game, the action has to be good enough to warrent the precise aiming mechanic.  I find it difficult to hit any given target, the mouse aiming seems more to get in the way than enhance the combat mechanics of the game.  I dunno, maybe it'd be more fun with a controller?

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												NOTE: Looks like the play timer is bugged Im sure i didnt play that long my ingame timer is much lower.Apotheon is an ancient greek action platformer. I dont like the art style, but i guess it fits the ancient greek theme. You can see it yourself in the trailer, if its a plus to you thats fine.Gameplay consists of going on various quests involving following arrows through the overworld to find mini dungeons scattered about that often have a boss in them and lots of purposeless corridors. Most of these quests never really had any explanation as to why I needed to do them, for example in the "Hades" area players must cross 4 rivers before fighting the areas boss. When you cross these rivers you come out back exactly where you started. It seem the only reason I had to do it was to add to the gameplay, not the story. However, many of these quests were very interesting and fun. This isn't nessicarily a fault. The problems come in with the platforming and combat.Platforming is quite obnoxious, it almost feels like im lagging but I dont think i am. Its very hard to move just a small amount or land on a small platform. Most areas are designed with "Z" shaped platforms, so youll often try to jump up onto one and lagging into the crook, because the jump didnt respond well. Also unresponsive is trying to down jump through a platform. This is very annoying when trying to run away. When you receive a big hit sometimes you go flying unpredictably. Also if your like me your used to roll jumping everywhere. Nope in this game you get to jump roll instead, thats a bit strange. There arent really that many parts in this game that require precise platforming anyways but its still annoying, especially on the final boss.Combat system is very simple but there are a ton of guards its much better to just run past most of them. When you do have to fight, despite the game insisting otherwise, you can just button mash with most weapons. Range weapons even have automatic aiming which is pretty OP. You can also make a ton of healing items using the crafting system. Even when you do die you aren't set back much by it.Theres this weird issue while trying to switch weapons while in combat where you cant do it while attacking. I would expect the game to finish the attack and then switch. When your weapon breaks this gets really annoying and makes it hard to use the more advanced potions at all.The UI also has weird overlapping issues very often.If your going to play it play it for an ancient greek story the gameplay is subpar. P.S. If your going to play it anyways you should note that the last difficulty is locked until you beat the game once but theres a bug you can do to skip to the final boss and get the acheivement for beating that difficulty without beating the whole game again.

Posted: December 5, 2015
												This is not a bad game, but it isn't good enough to warrant a definition recommendation.So far I'm a couple of hours in. - Combat is floaty and underwhelming and some attacks take a lot of time to 'wind up', which is especially frustrating against fast moving enemies. This is especially annoying in my current level filled with fast moving wolves.- Navigating between weapons in a fast paced combat is difficult and fiddly, but I'm on a controller. There isn't a function to map different weapons to D-pad, so you have to navigate to a menu item whilst being attacked in real time.- Boss fights are either not challenging, or a grind fest. For example, the boss I'm on has turned me into a deer and I have to dodge her arrows. Too bad she teleports - There's no real strategy involved for this boss match at least.- While the levels are visually distinct in colour themes and have good immersive music, they offer no variation in terms of gameplay. Most places have interchangeable map design.- Because each level is its own 'zone', there's little internal variation *within* levels, it's difficult to locate oneself and explore. The fast running and scrolling means you can move fast through the level, but actually counteracts exploring.I bought this on sale, I would not recommend this game for the full price of £10.99. It's a good attempt with some nice mechanics, but falls far short of what it tries to achieve. Overall the game seems to have developed from the art style, rather than the other way around. The game itself seems like a showcase of the pretty sprites and nuggets of the Iliad dotted around. Looking at the Steam achievements one can see that barely a third of all players made it to the end of the first level, so take that as an indication that this game loses its novelty quickly.

												I had seen mixed thoughts on this game, but thought I would give it a try.I'm always very interested in ancient greek mythology, so that in itself is a major draw to this game. While the story is very reminiscent of another greek mythology game (*cough* God of War *cough*), the way it was presented set it on its own.The art style is awesome, it's bold colors and just oozes with greek influence. It felt like I was playing a story book that was made by the ancient greeks themselves.  There is a nice variety of locals as well as your move throughout the story. While the graphics looked great, there were some slowdown issues with the framerate despite having a fairly powerful PC. They would come at random times, independant of what was going on during that particular moment.The other part of the game that made it a very positive experience for me was the combat. Its difficult, it has a high learning curve (in my opinion), but its *satisfying*. Once you figure out how you have to space yourself for different weapon types, and how you have to actually aim your ranged weapons, it becomes very natural. I was FRUSTRATED at first, so expect that, but know the more you practice with it, the better the game becomes. You can't expect to just run in and kill everything without timing your attacks and blocks, or you'll die horribly (as I did at first).There were a couple annoyances with the game I should mention too. For one, unless I missed some control, the map can't be moved around to search the area. This makes looking through a large map impossible, which is necessary sometimes when trying to figure out where treasure chests are, where an objective is located at specifically, or if you've already gone a certain way. Second, the weapon breaking system. It adds a degree of realism, and it allows you to try different weapons when one breaks, but it still was annoying. I enjoyed playing with the sword the most, but it always broke way too easily. I understand what the devs were trying to do with it, but it just detracts from the fun a bit in my opinion.TL;DR Overall, the game is a lot of fun, with great unique graphics, and very fun gameplay. The story is not very unique, but enjoyable. The map could use some tweaks, and the weapon breakage system detracts from the fun a bit. Still a highly recommended game!9/10

Posted: August 6, 2015
												By now it's likely that you've heard of Apotheon's art style. If not, it is the single most remarkable thing about this game. The whole thing is designed to look like an ancient Greek vase, and it is most effective. The primary colors are orange and black, to resemble the clay and dark ink of the artifacts, with blue on the protagonist's armor and red on those of the enemies, along with occasional changes in background color as is appropriate for each setting (Green for the forest, blue for the sea, and so on.) The art style and animation generate a terrific atmosphere, as well, ancient and mystical and desolate and hopeless. Aesthetically, Apotheon is an absolute masterpiece and deserves every mote of the attention it's gotten.The story is also excellent. With the dawning of the Iron Age, the Gods of Olympus are none too pleased with the direction that humanity has taken, and like Zeus's Christian counterpart, have decided to punish mankind with extinction. Demeter makes it so that nothing will grow, Poseiden stirs up the seas, Apollo denies the Earth light, and Artemis keeps the forests wanting for game. Enter Nikandreos, the hero. He wakes as his home village, Dion, is under attack by raiders. After defending the Temple of Hera from the outsiders, the Queen of Olympus charges Nikandreos with overthrowing Olympus and saving mankind. I won't say any more. While this isn't a game with a great many twists and turns, the development of the story is something you should uncover for yourself. The key here is that the developers really know their stuff when it comes to the Hellenic gods. Each one you meet fits their classical characterization to a tee, and this creates a number of great scenarios, my personal favorite being the Artemis boss fight. None of the gods are simplified or lionized as they have been in a great many modern sources, (God of War or Disney's Hercules this is not) and many of them have aligned against Zeus' abandonment of humanity. In addition, there is a liberal scattering of passages from classical Greek sources throughout the game, each placed to give you a clear impression of the particular obstacle or characters you'll be facing shortly. All in all, while the story itself may not be groundbreaking, it's well researched, well written, and creative, and is a joy to watch unfold.The gameplay is where Apotheon falls a little flat. Most of the time it's fine, your classic action platformer with just enough backtracking and exploration that it could be called a Metroidvania (Though that doesn't quite fit). There are two hubs, the Agora and the Acropolis, with a shop, and each is connected to three major levels each based around a particular god, as well as both having two optional gods each: Aphrodite and Dionysus in the Agora and Hermes and Hephaestus in the Acropolis. These aren't required for the core plot but they are fun, help flesh out the world and each bestows you with a useful upgrade.The place where the game falls short is the combat, specifically. I enjoyed it, don't get me wrong, but it was simply clunkier than it had to be. Essentially, you have three attacks, an uppercut, an overhead strike, and a thrust, in addition to a shield bash. With the exception of the shield bash, which is done by pressing the middle mouse button with the shield up, the rest are far too difficult to pull off consistently or accurately. For example, the overhead attack is done by moving the mouse up and attacking, the uppercut involves moving it down, and the thrust is done by keeping it still. The problem is, the mouse is also used for aiming the attack and controlling the direction Nikandreos is looking. Couple that with highly mobile enemies, a problem that only worsens late in the game with the introduction of flying enemies, and this means that you'll have a hard time predicting exactly how your strike will come out or where it will go. The best thing to do is "trade blows", attack, shield, attack, shield, and so on and so forth. However, this can be problematic in the frequent case that you're facing more than one enemy. At that point, I just used the bow and cheesed everything.This isn't fatal, and once you get the hang of it, can be pretty fun. It's just something that will catch you by surprise and can annoy you throughout the game. The other thing to know about the combat is the weapon system. This is not a negative point, but it will be a turn off for some players. Rather than having set weapons that you unlock and can use indefinitely, you have a wide selection of weapons that will break after some use. This has two effects on gameplay: First, you must be a generalist. You can't just stick with the Doru (Spear) or Xiphos (Sword), unless you want to put a great deal of effort into making sure you always have decent durability. Second, you have to learn to preserve the most powerful weapons for the situations where you need them, like you might save the BFG ammo in Doom rather than using it on an imp. As I said, it's not a mark against the game, it's just something not everyone will like.Is Apotheon a masterpiece? Certainly as a work of art. As a game, no, there's plenty of room for improvement. However, while it isn't perfect, it's still a very good time. Hell, the aesthetic alone is worth any gamer's time. I recommend it without reservation. Check it out, I think you'll like it.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												The concept of a greek mythology-inspired game may sound run-of-the-mill, but Apotheon is anything but. The game is a metroidvania type of action-platformer, but uses very little rpg elements, which simplifies the mechanics for players new to the genre.Your character does not level up, rather he gains extra health/protection and powers by upgrading his armor and weapons, and even honing his skill with select weapons such as the xiphos (sword) or spear.You move with the standard WASD, but use the mouse to aim, attack and block; this can be confusing for players who haven't experienced this type of controls, and this ends up muddling the combat. Often, the player will be stabbing blindly at the air, simply because the cursor isn't at the proper elevation. Likewise, this can affect the player's speed when moving if the cursor isn't in the direction the player is headed.The combat is not turn based, and most enemies can be dealt with only a few strikes of a sword or spear. However, enemies can pile up quickly and this is bothersome as running away is seldom a viable option considering the difficulties linked to platforming. The player is armed with only a modest jump and a stunted ledge grab to go through the levels.The visual style is deceptively modest, taking on the the style of ancient greek pottery of colour-on-black. The characters move mostly fluidly, bar some repeated motions during dialogues, and the background is almsot always filled with  ancient greek forests, cities and the like.Overall, Apotheon is a game that will frustrate the player in order to push them to do their best. The sometimes frustrating combat mechanics or platforming physics are easily overshadowed by the amazing visuals, immersive story and engaging gameplay.

												If I had to describe Apotheon in one word, it'd be fun.  Plain and simple, good ol' fashioned fun.Don't come into this game looking for an immersive novel-like story---it's just not there.  But like a beautifully illustrated children's book, Apotheon shines in its simplicity, style, and sense of adventure.  It's fun to play, and fun to watch.  The controls are simple and fluid.  The scenes are beautifully rendered in the style of Greek art.  It's truly a joy to behold.The soundtrack doesn't disappointment either, with a host of tunes that totally immerse the player into the environment, and convey the excitement (and sometimes anxiety), as you pit your mortal self against the mighty gods of Olympus.It's a must for any fans of Greek mythology, or anyone who enjoyed the Iliad or Odyssey.  Fans of simple, but fun adventure games will also find a lot to like here, as well as anyone who can appreciate games as art.To be fair, the story narrative could have been better integrated into the entirety of the game.  At times, it comes off feeling slightly arbitrary, or disjointed.  The side-plots also feel a bit confusing, and it's not clear most of the time how they fit in.  But, on the whole, the story is cogent, and it works for what the game is.  Again, in keeping with my earlier metaphor, think Chris Van Allsburg, not Leo Tolstoy.  My final grade for this beautifully rendered Greek odyssey:  B+.

"Atmospheric. Captivating Greek Theme. Great Attention to Detail. Slightly Flimsy Combat. Value for Money."Apotheon is a fun 2D platformer with a beautiful ancient greek pottery aesthetic. The story follows Nikandreos - a champion of humanity - who rises up against the Greek Gods to steal their powers and salvage the fate of his people. As Nikandreos, you will scale Mount Olympus and challenge the Gods in their respective realms.+ Apotheon's gameplay is quite solid, with plenty of interesting melee and ranged weaponry (historically-accurate ones included) to choose from, making for healthy variation in playing style.+ Great attention to detail is also displayed in level and character design, with each in-game location having a different feel and plenty of variation in the appearances of both NPCs and enemies.+ The music accompanies the game well and gives it great atmosphere, particularly during epic god fights. The lyre pieces, in particular, gives the game an elegant touch.+ The storyline is average with a cliché god-usurper plot. Nevertheless, it is well-executed.+ Game length is pretty substantial, well worth its price tag.+ A healthy level of appearance customization is available for the hero, from leather caps to wolf pelts to the iconic corinthian helmet.However,- Combat is slightly flimsy as attacks are completely mouse-dependent and can be annoyingly difficult to control when Nikandreos is surrounded by enemies, which happens fairly often.- The variety of actions available during melee combat is lacking, being limited to the usual stab or an upwards/overhead swing.- On a personal note, the amount of armor sets available for Nikandreos pales in comparison to the wide variety possessed by the NPCs, leaving something to be desired for a game so heavily focused on attaining excellent visuals.Overall, Apotheon is a good game with a composition of 55% style 45% gameplay. Its form similar to the pottery art it emulates: carefully crafted and artistically flavorful. A definite must-try if you dig its aesthetic and love classical history; a worth-trying if you're looking to play a fresh platformer.B+

There's 4 different categories of melee weapons, and then probably 5 or 6 different types within each category, and you can usually carry at least one of each type. When you combine that with all the shields, arrows, slings, potions, traps, etc, your inventory is quite difficult to manage.Finally, in my opinion the final boss fight area thing is utterly terrible. I found it so bad that rather than feeling like I achieved something, finishing the game just left a bad taste in my mouth. The entire section just completely ignored all the strengths of the game and used level designs and mechanics that emphasised everything that was wrong with the game.However, with the exception of the truly awful ending, I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and I would recommend it.

Posted: April 28, 2015
												I love this game unconditionally. I study history at my university, and I love Ancient Greece especially, and I could not stop geeking out over this game. It looks gorgeous, the story is great, and it is one of the most faithful approaches to the Greek myths I've ever seen. On top of that, it's damn fun. Athena's Labyrinth was probably my favorite zone, with all the cool skill challenges, but I was also a fan of the Underworld. The music and lighting down in Hades sometimes made me feel legitimately uneasy, and crossing the River Lethe was slow and tense without being frustrated. My only complaint is that the controls can be a bit sluggish when fighting, which is a bit of a problem in a platformer. Even then, combat made me feel like a badass. I should note, however, that I only played with an XBox controller, so a keyboard and mouse may be quicker and more precise. Other than that, no complaints. As a historian and lover of myth who loves to nitpick, I only noticed two historically inaccurate things: In the game, the sarissa can be held one-handed and thrown, and the pelta is carried on the arm. Besides the fact that these weapons were introduced in Macedonia several centuries after when this game seems to be set, the sarissa required two hands to use, and the pelta (which was invented to be used with the sarissa) was slung over the shoulder. But I digress. Long story short, play this game. Great story, great music, great history, and all-around fun.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												When I started to play this game I expected something a little different but, what I got was very good.  Visuals: The greek vase art style is perfect for this game and I never had to ask "What is that supposed to be?" and the way they color code is very clear: green for yourself and alies, blue for friendly's, red for enemies and no color for civilians. They also use this great effect when you take a heavy blow, a pottery crack will appear on screen to highlight what just happened.  Sound: The music while not necesarily award winning is very good in my opinion and can make the more epic moments of the game even better (I'm planning on getting the soundtrack once I've got some spare cash). The attack sounds clearly punctuate when you make contact with a target and when they make contact with you. I especially like how when a heavy blow is dealt or something dies you get a wooden drum type sound to accentuate what just happened. Gameplay: The combat is a little weird at first and not your typical metroidvania, but that is something that can be said about a lot of games (the little weird part, not the metroidvania part). I will say that Apotheon is better played on a gamepad because, it makes melee combat simpler since you don't have to actively aim your attacks and you have all your primary actions easily accesible at all times; but be sure to have a mouse near-by for the arrow aiming challenges (precise aiming with a joystick in this game is practicaly impossible). I do have a few gripes with the gameplay though. 1. if you want to pick a specific weapon to use, you may have to scroll through all the weapons you have of that type particularly melee and ranged (I never used that many bombs/traps or potions). 2. Even when using a gamepad my character would not be facing the right direction all the time in an intense fight (it was better than manualy aiming with a mouse though) also, the drop off for ranged weapons is probably a little to severe. 3. No wings, go to the acropolis for an explanation. 4. After you unlock most of the items on the blackmarket the screen can't show all the options at once. 5. Some item descriptions can't be entirely displayed unless viewed in the inventory, except one of the notes. But these issues may just be due to limited resources and are more of an issue of how refined the gameplay is.Finally, nearly all the bosses are either ingenious, epic or both and the the ones that fit into any of those categories are more of a test to see if you have a solid handle on the controls (the tutorial boss is a prime example of this). All the bosses are drawn from greek mythology and before you fight most of them, you read a passage of greek mythology to give you some context and an idea of who or what they are as well as what you need to know on how to beat them or what to watch out for. I only remember one or two mediocre bosses but, all these bosses are good examples of what a boss should be in a game. A test of everything you have learned and done to get to them. Not just a normal enemy that is a bit beefier than the others.To sum it up, this game is good, the visuals work perfectly for what this game is trying to be and the gameplay, once you've gotten use to it, it is solid despite it's minor flaws. Anyone who loves greek mythology and would like to see a different play on your average greek story that can make you think. (As you're playing think about the goal and objectives you are completing and ask if you're doing the right thing in context to the world that this is happening in, Classical Greece.) Also, I feel that this game is more greek than God of War is. The only thing you may ask for is a little more content, the game is fairly short. As for a sequel, no; the story prevents the game from having one by wrapping everything up in such a way that a direct sequel would just be tacked on for the sake of their being a sequel. A spiritual successor however, would be perfect. The gameplay was not just greek specific and I could see it being used in a Midieval or feudal Japan setting or if the developers wanted to stick with pantheons of gods norse mythology would be a good idea. The major problem I forsee is that they'd need to figure out a new art style to use. Regardless this game is definetly worth buying and at least finishing through to the end.

Posted: February 9, 2015
												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery.Gameplay: Let's be honest; it's kinda hard to describe at face value this game without comparing it to Dark Souls. The combat is similarly weighty, the hitboxes are very tight, there's a stamina gague involved, weapons/shields run out of endurance, you can have up to 10 health regen items on you at once... yeah, there's a lot of similarities to Dark Souls in this game. One thing that not a lot of people agree with me on is on the matter of controls: I think this game controls fantastically, albeit not exactly like you would expect. Moving is with the left analog stick; that much you can expect (oh yeah, also I really recommend playing this game with a gamepad), but with the right analog stick you adjust the angle of your weapon, meaning that if you're good enough at seeing the angles, you can very easily critical hit any enemy you run across. Critical hits are headshots, for reference. Blocking is with the left trigger and attacking is with the right trigger. It does take a few minutes to get used to, but once you do, it feels very natural. As far as the enemies go, they usually have a combination of ranged and melee attacks. They also usually come in waves of four to five, so spacing is definitely something you wanna keep in mind. These enemies are all pretty fun to fight, and it's never an enemy swarm that feels unfair or overwhelming. I will say that the final area could've been one section shorter and have been perfectly fine. As for the boss fights, they're all pretty fun as well. There's plenty in there to keep things interesting, and they usually have their own clever mechanics (even if there are a couple of "giant dude" fights).This game really doesn't have much of an RPG element to it like the Souls series does. In fact, pretty much the only thing you get in the way of upgrades are armor upgrades or abilities you unlock from defeating certain gods. Apart from that, you've got currency and a rather meager crafting system (which feels kinda shoehorned in, to be perfectly honest) and that's your lot. Regarding the difficulty, I'd definitely recommend putting this game on Hard for your first time through if you happen to be a veteran of the Souls series, as this game can be a bit disappointing in terms of challenge if you're just going on Normal. Even on Normal it does offer some resistance, albeit a resistance of size and not of force, if you understand where I'm going with this. I only died once, and that was because I wasn't paying attention.Even though my first playthrough only took me about five hours, I could see myself playing this game again in the future (more specifically on Hard Mode). It's a pretty darn competent 2D action game with a pretty good amount of challenge and fun. While not anywhere near being GOTY material, I'd say $15 ain't a half bad price for this. 8/10Story: I'm not too well versed in Greek mythology, so I can't say with certainty how well this game follows the source material, but from what was presented, it wasn't bad. The writing does feel a bit romp-y at times in that it feels like we're going to beat up all these gods for the sake of beating up the gods (and collecting their powers, of course). The core storyline of the game is, "Zeus is a butt, Hera gets mad, go hit Zeus with your wepon." Dialogue is... well, it serves its purpose and nothing more. There isn't much in the way of twists (at least none that I called from a hundred miles away), so to be perfectly honest, the plot ain't gonna impress you. It does serve its purpose, and it does so pretty well, so I'll give it a 7/10.Graphics: Well, it's meant to look like ancient Greek bronze art, and it does. The way that the sprites were handled can get a bit silly at times, though. Basically, sprites in this game are jointed together, kinda like what you would expect from Flash animation. As such, sometimes the sprites rotate a bit too far and loop around or separate entirely, and it all just looks kinda silly. On the matter of optimization, I do feel like this game shouldn't be demanding as much from my system as it does. It's by no means a system destroyer, but it does warm my GPU up a bit (about 50degC for my GTX 760), which does seem rather odd for a 2D game. I suspect this is because of the lighting engine. Either way, I didn't have any frame dropping issues or overheating, but I will say that it maybe could've been optimized a bit better. The art is definitely stylish, but the obvious jointing could definitely get a few unintentional laughs out of you, and it does feel like the game could run a little lighter. 3/5.Sound: Again, the comparison arises to Dark Souls: it does feel like the composer kinda tried to use Sakuraba's style for the boss fights, but they didn't quite match the overwhelmingly anthemic nature of Sakuraba's work in Dark Souls. It's not bad, and in fact for an indie studio an orchestral recording is quite good; it's just that Sakuraba's work exists. The sound design is really, really good on the other hand, as well as the more subtle and ambient tracks this game has to offer. A couple of standout areas are the hunt for the Chimera and Hades. Those areas are very well done. The voice acting is pretty good as well. Nothing that's gonna blow you away, but it's quite a bit better than dev voiceovers. All in all, they did a pretty darn good job here in the audio department. While the boss themes could've had a bit more oomph, the subtleties are all very well done. 4/5.Overall scores are: 8/7/3/4; cumulative score of 7.3/10. I'd definitely say this game is worth your time if you like games like the Souls series. Just don't expect a Souls game and you'll be fine.

Posted: February 17, 2015
												Apotheon is a beautiful little game.  First of all. the artwork and game presentation and design is beautiful.  Have you seen images of those ancient Greek and Minoan frescos painted on walls?  This game looks and feels like you just stepped inside one of these.  The detail is exquisite in these handcrafted levels and environments.  It shows how so much can seemingly be done with so little.  For only being a 2D sidescrolling and platforming game, the creators have done and excellent job immersing and transporting one to an ancient and mythical time and place.  Its easy to see that a lot of love went into this project.The gameplay is equally great.  As previously mentioned it plays like a classic, sidescrolling, platforming game.  It has a slight RPG mechanic in that you have an inventory, certain gear can be equiped there, and some minor crafting can be done using items you collect.  For me the real treat in gameplay has to do with weapons.  There are tons of them.  They all have a purpose wether miniscule or more impactful.  Not only are there specifically ranged weapons, all weapons can be thrown anyway.  So you can chuck a crappy wood club you found at an enemy or one of my favorites, the darts or dorus spears.  You also can pick up shields with some being better than others and some actually having special characteristics.As far as movement goes it feels great.  Your little 2D character is nicely articulated.  You can walk, run, jump, roll, climb, hang and hand-over-hand, squat, stealth kill from behind and so on.  There are also physics implented which I always love to see even and especially in a minimalistic game like this.The music is outstanding.  Its ethereal.  Almost like a combination of Enya, Loreena McKennitt and the soundtrack to Gladiator.  And its infused into the game in such a way that its not abrupt or inappropriate but instead is incidental and purposed for the particular environment that you are in or situation.  The sound effects are also well done.  On par with the music is the voice acting.  Very well done and it adds more depth and richness to the game actually hearing others talk making the world more alive.  Story and lore can effortlessly be gleaned from hearing these soundbites or even clicking on pedestals/monuments throughout the game that bring up excerpts from apparently ancient texts and stories such as things Homer has written.(whether these are actual quotations from actual documents or creative liscense I don't know but it adds more depth to the game's setting and story)I was also pleasantly suprised to see that the base levels on the game's map themselves often have sublevels.  I even got lost once in one. :)  Overall I am very pleased with this little gem of a game.  I would absolutely love seeing these developers putting this same treatment into other games dealing with subjects and times in history or fiction such as the Japanese Samurai, a Western, Tolkein story and so on.So far some of the things I've gotten to do in this game include slaying the Tyrant named Ophion where upon which the wife of Zeus tasked me with pursuing her husband where then I was portaled, ascending into the realm of Olympus, aquired the Bow of Artemis, wandered into Aphrodite's chambers, was thrown into prison for provoking Apollo, killed a towering cyclops with my sling shot and Olympian darts and then released three solar steeds from their stables.  Great game and good fun.

"Atmospheric. Captivating Greek Theme. Great Attention to Detail. Slightly Flimsy Combat. Value for Money."Apotheon is a fun 2D platformer with a beautiful ancient greek pottery aesthetic. The story follows Nikandreos - a champion of humanity - who rises up against the Greek Gods to steal their powers and salvage the fate of his people. As Nikandreos, you will scale Mount Olympus and challenge the Gods in their respective realms.+ Apotheon's gameplay is quite solid, with plenty of interesting melee and ranged weaponry (historically-accurate ones included) to choose from, making for healthy variation in playing style.+ Great attention to detail is also displayed in level and character design, with each in-game location having a different feel and plenty of variation in the appearances of both NPCs and enemies.+ The music accompanies the game well and gives it great atmosphere, particularly during epic god fights. The lyre pieces, in particular, gives the game an elegant touch.+ The storyline is average with a cliché god-usurper plot. Nevertheless, it is well-executed.+ Game length is pretty substantial, well worth its price tag.+ A healthy level of appearance customization is available for the hero, from leather caps to wolf pelts to the iconic corinthian helmet.However,- Combat is slightly flimsy as attacks are completely mouse-dependent and can be annoyingly difficult to control when Nikandreos is surrounded by enemies, which happens fairly often.- The variety of actions available during melee combat is lacking, being limited to the usual stab or an upwards/overhead swing.- On a personal note, the amount of armor sets available for Nikandreos pales in comparison to the wide variety possessed by the NPCs, leaving something to be desired for a game so heavily focused on attaining excellent visuals.Overall, Apotheon is a good game with a composition of 55% style 45% gameplay. Its form similar to the pottery art it emulates: carefully crafted and artistically flavorful. A definite must-try if you dig its aesthetic and love classical history; a worth-trying if you're looking to play a fresh platformer.B+

												If I had to describe Apotheon in one word, it'd be fun.  Plain and simple, good ol' fashioned fun.Don't come into this game looking for an immersive novel-like story---it's just not there.  But like a beautifully illustrated children's book, Apotheon shines in its simplicity, style, and sense of adventure.  It's fun to play, and fun to watch.  The controls are simple and fluid.  The scenes are beautifully rendered in the style of Greek art.  It's truly a joy to behold.The soundtrack doesn't disappointment either, with a host of tunes that totally immerse the player into the environment, and convey the excitement (and sometimes anxiety), as you pit your mortal self against the mighty gods of Olympus.It's a must for any fans of Greek mythology, or anyone who enjoyed the Iliad or Odyssey.  Fans of simple, but fun adventure games will also find a lot to like here, as well as anyone who can appreciate games as art.To be fair, the story narrative could have been better integrated into the entirety of the game.  At times, it comes off feeling slightly arbitrary, or disjointed.  The side-plots also feel a bit confusing, and it's not clear most of the time how they fit in.  But, on the whole, the story is cogent, and it works for what the game is.  Again, in keeping with my earlier metaphor, think Chris Van Allsburg, not Leo Tolstoy.  My final grade for this beautifully rendered Greek odyssey:  B+.

												An excelent game with solid mechanics, innovate design, and a high degree of polish. The campaign offers many hours of gameplay, which constantly introduces variety and rarely repeats itself. Well worth buying outside of a sale.You play as a greek warrior from the archaic period fighting the greek gods on Mount Olympus, whom are attempting to clean up the earth by doing away with humanity. The story won't win any awards, but it serves its purpose of setting the scene well, and doesn't bog down the player in unnecessary details. It is, however, very well-researched, and proves it through excepts from ancient greek culture spread out on readible plaques spread throughout the game world (safely ignorable by those uninterested in such things). The artwork is beautifully drawn and heavily inspired from ancient pottery, while at the same time making important details very noticable to the player. Variety is the spice that makes this game special. The world is laid out in a metroidvania-style arrangement of hubs with branching off areas for each god. Each god's area carries with it a different theme, with different goals, enemies, and backgrounds; each in turn has subregions within. The contrasts are well-balanced, providing enough time for the player to learn new tactics and strategies in each zone, and often lessons learned in one place will prove useful in others. But (perhaps more importantly) it isn't always *necessary* to learn new tactics all the time: the player can usually power through but with a greater cost in resources. However, there's a certain satisfaction to be had in going out of one's way to sneak up behind an opponent merely so that dagger with 800% backstab damage doesn't languish in one's inventory forever.I cannot find a single major problem with the game, but I do have a few nitpicks. For instance, inventory gets cluttered after a while and there are like ten times as many lockpicks as locked doors. it's also annoying how smashing crates reduces weapon durability and that the stacking limit on crafting ingrediants is so low. But those are like tiny chips on an ancient vase: the basic quality of the item remains the same.

												UPDATED. Just finished the game, and my opinion is unchanged from my initial impressions. I adore this game and enjoyed very nearly every minute of it. Combat is a little awkward; there are a few glitchy things, and I crashed a few times... but it's all forgivable, because this game feels like it was made just for me.This is the only game I can recall where the mythology was truly given a proper treatment. It's woven into the entire game and presented with care and affection. I've been fascinated with Greek mythology since I was a child, and am not used to seeing it presented with such fidelity in any entertainment medium. I enjoyed Disney's animated Hercules film, and the first two God of War games on Playstation, but in either one of those cases the mythology could have been swapped with entirely original characters and no one would have known the difference. Here, the mythology IS the story, and it's done very well. And I am in love with the visuals: the varied color palettes, the silhouetted Greek pottery art style complete with texture and lighting overlay and simulated imperfections. I could stare at it forever; it's gorgeous... and the music is wonderful, too.Yet it's so difficult to unconditionally recommend the game, and the combat and controls are the reason. Using mouse and keyboard, the game controls like Terraria: Move with WASD, jump with spacebar, and control your weapons with the mouse, pointing the cursor around the screen to determine the direction you will strike. You will either be okay with these controls, or you will hate them. Personally, I thought they worked pretty well most of the time. I didn't love the apparent inability to choose how I was going to swing my weapon, but I didn't find it much of an issue on the normal difficulty, which is a little on the easy side. Now if I spent a few hours on Olympian difficulty, I might feel much differently. I haven't decided whether I'm going to attempt that yet.Overall, though, I am thoroughly impressed with this game. Loved it, loved it.

												Firstly. my review mostly lists the problems I had, since you're probably already interested in the game for whatever reason and wondering what might be bad about it.  I definitely played the game all the way through and enjoyed it, especially the boss fights.  The art style is brilliant, and the story is interesting enough (although I don't expect anything epic from a platformer).  I played with an Xbox 360 controller and the movement and controls are mostly solid.The combat was a bit awkward.  It's just impractical to try to aim your weapon AND shield properly with the right thumbstick at the same time while moving around with the left.  I never got used to it.  The weapon switching with a controller is a joke too.  It's impossible to accurately choose one of dozens of weapons with the d-pad in the middle of combat.   You have to pause the game and switch in the inventory screen if you don't want to be carved up while finding the right weapon.  The being said, the combat does take a little bit of brains to know when to attack and with what against whom.My biggest problem was the weapon/shield breaking mechanic.  Some weapons are more useful against a lot of foes, and some are kind of niche.  You tend to want to save the useful ones for potentially harder fights because they break so fast.  This means sometimes you're using terrible weapons against certain weaker foes just to hold onto the good weapons.  Shields break way too fast for you to be blocking with any regularity as well.  You do get a fair bit of replacement weapons, but you never know when the next good weapon or good shield is coming up, so I tended to try to conserve, which threw any battle strategy in the trash (there are so many health potions you can just keep healing instead of fighting well).  I feel like it would be a lot more fun if at least shields (and preferably weapons) were indestructible, because then you could use the weapons/shields to fit the strategy per enemy instead of playing resource management.  It's not unplayable by any means, just a moderate annoyance.

Posted: March 6, 2015
												Apotheon is a game about defying the Greek gods. They have abandoned mankind, so you must seek their assistance or kill them and gain their powers to save man yourself. The combat in the game is straighforward, as to be expected in a 2D action game; click to attack with melee weapons, which is done with a thrust or swing, and movement is done with the WASD keys. Ranged weapons can be thrown or launched with a bow, sling, or other devices. You can even pick up and throw boulders or stone blocks for massive damage. The difficulty on the default difficulty setting is ridiculously easy, and the next setting really isn't much harder. I think I only died a couple of times. Beating the game unlocks the hardest difficulty, which I have yet to attempt. It's a lot more fun than this simple explanation can make it sound, so I reccomend looking up a youtube video of gameplay if you don't get the picture yet. Also, there is a lot of exploration. There are a lot of goodies to be found if you just look in the right places. There is also not much backtracking, so you don't need to worry if you don't like that sort of thing.As for the presentation of the game, the art style is done in a Greek pottery fashion. There's a filter that applies to the whole screen, the colors are those that would be used in ancient greek pottery, and the screen will crack if you take too much damage. It is very nice to look at. The music, however, is lackluster. Sometimes it is not even present, and when it is, it does not stand out at all.So, overall, is the game good? Yes, it's very good. The combat is fun and you will have to plan out strategies for dealing with enemies on the fly. Environments are big and there are many secrets to discover. Honestly, the only nitpick I have is the music. Other than that, though, the game is stellar. Originally I thought I would not like this game, but when I bought it, I was very impressed. A playthrough lasted me 12 hours, and it was fun the whole way through. If you like 2D action games with some exploration in them, it's hard not to reccomend this.

												I think I've found a new favorite sidescroller; it isn't all that often that one of those comes around where I don't roll my eyes and leave it after the first half hour. Pros:- Story. The story strays into the cliche at times, but otherwise is wonderfully crafted and engaging- Voice acting. This is something plenty games, especially sidescrollers, lack. The voice acting is spot on- Depth. The game has plenty locations to explore and plenty treasures to find, keeping the player interested and roaming- Accuracy. This is something I didn't expect, but the game tosses out old terms and quotes from the Greek poets and        Homer with astonishing regularity. This really helps the world connect back to the ancient Greek roots, unlike plenty other that wore the "Ancient Greek" label.- Varied Gameplay. Instead of being same-old, shoot-this kill-that, the game actively switches it up between puzzles, races, platforming challenges, and kill-them-all brawls interspersed with the occassional boss fight or conversation with an NPC. This helps it stay fresh for longer and is a welcome addition- Music. While it may not be to everyone's tastes, the music is hauntingly beautiful if somewhat repetitive after a time- Balance. This sort of game always has trouble balancing between frustratingly dificult and too easy. Apotheon manages it. There were definitely moments of sheer panic where I felt like I was being crushed, but these never crossed the line into an annoyingly hard fight.- Replayability. The first run through, without seeking out side quests or the like, on the easiest settings, takes about 12 hours. Have fun. I persume it will take another 12 on the next difficulty, and a lot more than that on Olympian.Cons:- Controls. Yes, let's talk about the one major failing that this game has; the controls. They aren't all that bad, but suffer on two points: Firstly, platforming is a bit of a nuisance. The game makes you stick to any climbable surface you touch, theoretically making platform puzzles easier but also slowing you down at inopportune moments. Furthermore, archery and thrown weapons are the slightest bit inaccurate and hard to master early on.- Tutorial. The first mission is in essence a tutorial mission. It gives you all the basics, but no more, leaving you to puzzle out the rest on your own. Where do I get more crafting recipes? Wait, my weapons can break? Can I repair them? These questions and more are left to the player to decipher. On the one hand, this can be enjoyable if the player enjoys the challenge and the thrill of discovering something new. On the other, people who want to jump straight in may suffer a few mishaps - I myself ended up fighting a boss with only one spear as my other weapons had worn down.Despite the slightly sticky controls and the imperfect tutorial, this game is still excellent. If you enjoy sidescrollers, story-driven adventure games, or Greek mythology, this game is a perfect fit and I anticipate having a lot of fun with it.

TL;DR (Complete comment below)PROS+ Beautiful and neat art style (graphics, soundtrack, atmosphere...)+ Great gameplay, controls easy to take in hand+ Great variety in weapons+ Balanced and progressive difficulty+ The PRICE for such a quality gameCONS- Some rare physics glitches (items or arrows stuck in mid-air)- Bosses fight could have had more "strategical" aspects- Lacks customization / stats complexity? (Well, that's no RPG, but I would have appreciated some optimization options)- Disappointing "hardest" difficulty level, which is quite the same as the "hard" difficultyFINALLY...8/10, must have indie game for anyone liking 2D action platformer gameApotheon reminds me that videogames can be WORKS OF ART on their own, not only for the graphics, the soundtrack, the animations, but by combining all of these to make an amazing and pleasant experience.COMPLETE COMMENTThis game seduced me with its art style (it's not just beautiful, but also neat and refined) and convinced me with its gameplay, which requires well-timed attacks and dodges, using the right weapon / potion at the right time, diving in the melee like a true warrior, and even sometimes avoiding useless fights.After the first mission which could be considered as a tutorial, you'll be able to chose between two difficulty levels:- The Warrior (easy) one should be adapted for casual gamers and people who want to explore the levels without being threatened much by the enemies- The Champion (hard) difficulty provides a decent challenge and requires to understand well the fighting mechanics and the different enemies- The Olympian difficulty, unlocked when finishing the game once, quite disappointing: it's the same as the Champion one, but without life autoregen when it drops below 50. Don't see the point... Maybe limitting the number of possible saves or save frequency, or giving the enemies more damages / HP would have been great to make this difficulty level worth it.To beat the game, you will be given a variety of weapons with different attack power and range (and sometimes additional effects), but that will break easily, requiring to have a good set of weapons in your inventory before diving in fights. You'll also have armours giving you damage mitigation, and various potions that will become handy (not to say vital) in many situations.The quite rare physics glitches I encountered weren't quite a problem (it's just strange to see an arrow floating in mid-air, as the rest of the game seems just perfect).For "serial achievers", you'll need to explore every bit of every map to find the hidden keys, chests and rare weapons, which shouldn't take you too much time but still feels rewarding and pleasant.I'm definitely convinced that this game is simply better, funnier and more challenging than many 60+$ games.

												I love this game unconditionally. I study history at my university, and I love Ancient Greece especially, and I could not stop geeking out over this game. It looks gorgeous, the story is great, and it is one of the most faithful approaches to the Greek myths I've ever seen. On top of that, it's damn fun. Athena's Labyrinth was probably my favorite zone, with all the cool skill challenges, but I was also a fan of the Underworld. The music and lighting down in Hades sometimes made me feel legitimately uneasy, and crossing the River Lethe was slow and tense without being frustrated. My only complaint is that the controls can be a bit sluggish when fighting, which is a bit of a problem in a platformer. Even then, combat made me feel like a badass. I should note, however, that I only played with an XBox controller, so a keyboard and mouse may be quicker and more precise. Other than that, no complaints. As a historian and lover of myth who loves to nitpick, I only noticed two historically inaccurate things: In the game, the sarissa can be held one-handed and thrown, and the pelta is carried on the arm. Besides the fact that these weapons were introduced in Macedonia several centuries after when this game seems to be set, the sarissa required two hands to use, and the pelta (which was invented to be used with the sarissa) was slung over the shoulder. But I digress. Long story short, play this game. Great story, great music, great history, and all-around fun.

Posted: May 20, 2015
												If I had to describe Apotheon in one word, it'd be fun.  Plain and simple, good ol' fashioned fun.Don't come into this game looking for an immersive novel-like story---it's just not there.  But like a beautifully illustrated children's book, Apotheon shines in its simplicity, style, and sense of adventure.  It's fun to play, and fun to watch.  The controls are simple and fluid.  The scenes are beautifully rendered in the style of Greek art.  It's truly a joy to behold.The soundtrack doesn't disappointment either, with a host of tunes that totally immerse the player into the environment, and convey the excitement (and sometimes anxiety), as you pit your mortal self against the mighty gods of Olympus.It's a must for any fans of Greek mythology, or anyone who enjoyed the Iliad or Odyssey.  Fans of simple, but fun adventure games will also find a lot to like here, as well as anyone who can appreciate games as art.To be fair, the story narrative could have been better integrated into the entirety of the game.  At times, it comes off feeling slightly arbitrary, or disjointed.  The side-plots also feel a bit confusing, and it's not clear most of the time how they fit in.  But, on the whole, the story is cogent, and it works for what the game is.  Again, in keeping with my earlier metaphor, think Chris Van Allsburg, not Leo Tolstoy.  My final grade for this beautifully rendered Greek odyssey:  B+.

												Yes.Story:The game is simple: You're mad at Zues for being a♥♥♥♥♥♥so you're going to teach him a lesson or two. So with the help of his wife Hera you go on an adventure to gain favor from the other goods in whatever way you can. I wont speak much more because your interactions with the various gods were pretty interesting, despite 80% of them being "♥♥♥♥ you mortal, I'm gonna kill you".Gameplay:CombatThe combat is simple with just enough variety and nuance to keep it interesting. You have melee weapons with varied reach, attack speeds, and damage. Then you have your ranged weapons such as differnent types of bows, slingshot spears, and even firebombs. There are so many kinds of weapons that you'll never feel stuck once the durability of one dies out, but because there are so many, you'll eventually find one or two that you really like and end up using it the whole game with the exception of some of the bigger enemies who seem to take different types of damage from different weapons without any clear reason. The game was so short that I felt like I didnt get to use everything, but I wont fault the game for allowing me to find my niche and not punishing me for it. There are also some fights that you can cheese because of the way some of the level are designed. +1 for things you can only do in video games like Slashing horses in the buttcheeks through floors[/spoilers]Travel/SceneryTraveling from area to area isn't hard, but I did feel like the map was a little difficult to read at parts and was thankful for the ever helpful arrow telling me where to go. That being said, you are encouraged to explore as you will often find upgrades to your armor, materials for the simple  crafting system, and replacement for your broken down weapons. And some of these maps are big.ControlsOther than than the combat which did feel "floaty" at times, moving around is not hard, there this fun little mechanic where if you keep running in one direction you will eventually pick up speed into a full sprint, but you will ever run in one direction for too long.The platforming was good enough, but there was this little quirk where you can stick to certain ledges and slanted parts of the geometry that I never fully understood. It was helpful, but non-obvious.My biggest problem with this game was swithing through weapons and various tools. I played this entire game on an X360 controller and the Dpad on this thing is horrendous, I ended up using the wrong tool or weapon very often and since you end up carrying so many different item by the end, switching in the middle of a fight was a real pain, I would have appreciated either a radial menu, or having the game stop time while I reached into the infinite space that was my pants pocket.ConclusionWhile the controls might be floaty, the map kind of vague, and the game short I highly recommend this game.Each area you go to is varied and different enough to keep things fresh, you can play the game at your own pace, either explore everything or beat down ♥♥♥♥♥es with your hammer of justice. The combat is simple, but fun, seeing hordes of olympian guards fly through the map after laying down the law was a treat. The boss fights are simple enough not think to hard, but simple misteps will cost you a bit of health and armor.Finally this game looks and sounds amazing. The voice acting was very convincing and the art style is mesmerizing. From water to fire to lighthing it all looked great and the art team did not skimp on the bloodiness that were the Ancient Greeks.The time involved wasnt a huge commitment which for me was a godsend (pun intended) because I favor short and sweet experiences over those that drag on. My final word was that this game is fun, fast, beautiful and, and offers a great experience.TL;DR This game gud, kill gods, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up.

Posted: February 9, 2016
												UPDATED. Just finished the game, and my opinion is unchanged from my initial impressions. I adore this game and enjoyed very nearly every minute of it. Combat is a little awkward; there are a few glitchy things, and I crashed a few times... but it's all forgivable, because this game feels like it was made just for me.This is the only game I can recall where the mythology was truly given a proper treatment. It's woven into the entire game and presented with care and affection. I've been fascinated with Greek mythology since I was a child, and am not used to seeing it presented with such fidelity in any entertainment medium. I enjoyed Disney's animated Hercules film, and the first two God of War games on Playstation, but in either one of those cases the mythology could have been swapped with entirely original characters and no one would have known the difference. Here, the mythology IS the story, and it's done very well. And I am in love with the visuals: the varied color palettes, the silhouetted Greek pottery art style complete with texture and lighting overlay and simulated imperfections. I could stare at it forever; it's gorgeous... and the music is wonderful, too.Yet it's so difficult to unconditionally recommend the game, and the combat and controls are the reason. Using mouse and keyboard, the game controls like Terraria: Move with WASD, jump with spacebar, and control your weapons with the mouse, pointing the cursor around the screen to determine the direction you will strike. You will either be okay with these controls, or you will hate them. Personally, I thought they worked pretty well most of the time. I didn't love the apparent inability to choose how I was going to swing my weapon, but I didn't find it much of an issue on the normal difficulty, which is a little on the easy side. Now if I spent a few hours on Olympian difficulty, I might feel much differently. I haven't decided whether I'm going to attempt that yet.Overall, though, I am thoroughly impressed with this game. Loved it, loved it.

Posted: September 12, 2016
												The outstanding art and theme really outshine most of the problems with this fun and immersive game about man and god duking it out in ancient Greece. This is a game in the style of Metroid where dungeons/levels can be tackled in any order.The game aims to resemble a rotating vase of Greek origin and succeeds magnificiently.  It looks like you are playing a game on a piece of ancient greek pottery.  The unique art style and story wasn't thrown together in a couple hours; the developers really did their research when it came to Greek mythology and captured all the flaws and craziness of Greek dieties.  There are flavor text signposts all around the world and great voice acting.  The final climb up to Zeus is awesome and has memorable voice acting.  Levels and boss battles are unique; my favorite was the fight against Artemis when you alternate between deer and hunter.Unforunately there are a couple flaws which may turn off some people.  The game is physics based so fighting and jumping is "floaty". Control is not precise like a Metroid game.  Also, the inventory management is a mess and there are way too many weapons and items.  I understand the developers wanted to give the players choices but there are too many weapons to cycle through during combat and selecting items is a similar pain.  There should have been fewer weapons and items or you should have been able to set certain items to quick keys/buttons.  I recommend a controller for maximum enjoyment but still expect to be frustrated by the inventory system.I understand the game will not be for everyone but give it a chance (at least until a boss fight) as I think the developers did a great job capturing the world of ancient Greek gods in video game form.

												This game will probably stay in my list of top 10 games of 2015. And that's thanks to the amazing art, beautiful music, solid fighting mechanics, and variety of levels. It also removes the need to backtrack through areas you've already been only to open up new sections of it which can be a bit tedious. I feel they have really found a good balance in their gameplay.The variety in the levels is another huge plus for Apotheon. You usually have to do 3 tasks before facing off against a God, and they have made each level unique to the God you're fighting. Posted: March 5, 2016
												You begin in a ravaged town, scavenging for crude weapons in true farmer militia fashion as you battle back marauding pillagers. The tone is desolate, and horror surrounds you; you must fight your way out of the darkness. The combat system is slasher, and reminds me of Mountain Blade or Chivalry; with timing, postioning, and range being important factors of success. Ultimately, however, I found the combat to be clunky and a bit unsatisfiying with a feeling of weightlessness. Not that the combat is bad, it is fine, but it is hardly the games selling point. The gameplay really shines when scenarios of total warfare erupt and really serve of the striking imagery of the game. The visuals are truly what make this game stick; it is as if you "watching" a piece of art, rather than playing a video game...  Apotheon is the perfect example of an art style setting a game apart from its competition, In fact, nothing about Apotheon is unique or compelling except for the greek-themed art direction. The game is an open-world, side-scrolling action RPG and it performs quite well in that capacity, but; you should buy it because it is pretty.

Posted: March 5, 2016
												I had decided to take a break from my usual gaming direction revolving around waifu bait and Japanime, and turned my attention towards my second favorite culture, Greek Mythology.  In addition to offering surprisingly fun platforming gameplay, Apotheon does a great job of capturing the essence of the Olympian gods and their attitudes.  Especially Hera.  Zeus must have slept with a really hot mortal girl to get Hera that riled up.  The only gripe I would have is the Nephilim tier main character, Nikandreos.  Who evidently is a mortal capable of running around Olympus and slaying everything, including the gods.  They were called immortals for a reason, you know.  But I guess staying 100% true to the lore and having Zeus send him straight to Hades in the first five minutes would have made for a lousy game, so I'll give them a pass on that.  All and all, it was a wildly enjoyable game that any fan of Greek myth should like.  It even has a Dionysus drinking game!10/10...I'll never forget you, Athena. Not ever.

												I don't usually write reviews, but this game deserves one.It's graphics are gorgeous as it replicates greek arts and style. Combat is clever and kept fresh since it forces you to constantly use different weapons since they have limited duribility. You might think this will be annoying, but it isn't. Each type of weapon are good in their own way. I ended up using maybe around 15 different kind of melee weapons by the end of the game; this includes tridents, flaming swords, iron rods, and spears (my favorite). I can say the same for ranged weapons as well. You can use arrows, hatchets, and more.The map design is well done. In the grand scheme of things, the entire map is split into themes that match a personality of the associated gods. Ares, god of war, rules over a bloody, trap-filled, chaotic battler areana. Athena, goddess of wisdom, has a revolving maze. Each theme can and will change the way you battle your enemies.The story is brought to life thanks to the great voice acting. If you have played God of War, this story will seem very similar since you have to deal with different gods.Overall I would definitely recommend this game! If you have around 10-12 hours of spare time, use it on Apotheon.

Posted: July 1, 2015
												Apotheon is a fantastic adventure/side-scroller. The art is beautiful, the story is great, the fighting system is pretty solid. There's plenty to do but not so much that you'll be overwhelmed. I usually don't feel led to accomplish a ton of side quests that only amount to extra loot or require a lot of running around, but something about Apotheon genuinely made me want to. Maybe it was the rich world the story takes place in, I'm not quite sure, but it was something I've found lacking in a lot of other similar games that give you free reign to explore.Sure, the game has its setbacks. Sometimes you get absolutely bombarded by enemies and it gets repetitive or stressful, the default controls can be a bit awkward (especially if you're left-handed like me, even though I'm used to having to mess around with controls for Steam games), and the game has crashed on me a couple time, but it auto-saves frequently, so it's generally no big deal. I also adore how the developers took so much time to research and properly implement different aspects of ancient Greek mythology, art, and culture into the game, you can tell a lot of love went into it. This game has made it into my top 10 favorite video games in record time, and I'm definitely looking forward to whatever the developer, Alien Trap is planning next.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												As a classicist I may be a little biased, but I really enjoyed this game. The black-figure art style is what initially attracted me and made Apotheon an instant buy. Both the art and the music are beautiful, and the inclusion of quotations from the Homeric hymns and other source materials was a nice touch, and much appreciated.About the only (relatively minor) negative thing I could say about the game is that I felt that despite the huge variety in weapons and items, it didn't really seem to matter much what I used. I just picked something and only really switched when it broke or if it just wasn't getting the job done. Usually this just meant a switch from melee to ranged on a few bosses that seemed to call for it, and the occasional enemy like peltasts or mechanical sentries that were difficult to get in melee range of, rather than any specific weapon choice within those classifications. Given the realtive speed with which equipment breaks though, I did get a chance to use pretty much everything the game had to offer, however. Despite my slight ambivalence toward the combat in general, the variety in boss fights and trials, from brawling with Ares  and hunting Artemis, to traversing Athena's shifting labyrinth, to the time trials such as Dionysus' drinking contest and crossing the river Phlegethon in Hades, kept things fresh and entertaining. The encounters and puzzles were well done and provided an adequate level of challenge, but nothing proved particularly difficult. So, I might have liked to have the option to play on Olympian difficulty from the beginning, rather than have to unlock it by beating the game. There is a decent amount of content in the way of optional/side-quests to satisfy the completionist as well.All in all, Apotheon was a very enjoyable experience and highly recommended! Well done to Alientrap for this gem.
